entry.title: Re: How does the Inventory Audit Report calculation work...
entry.content:
Hi,

B1 uses all tables that influence either stock, stock value, or both. So for example RDR1 and ORDR (Sales Order data), it does not use, but DLN1 and ODLN (Sales Delivery data), it does use. It depends entirely on which modules and functions of B1 you use. You can use the System Information functionality, from the 'View' menu, to see which tables are used in your report:

Turn it on > run the report with a single item and a year time span > open one of each type of transation that is shown in the report, using the yellow arrows, one at a time > hover (no need to click) the mouse pointer over a field and look at the bottom left corner:

The report chooses all items that have the 'Inventory item' check set, within the parameters that you have given:

The report is generated from scratch each time. It simply adds and subtracts quantities based on all trasactions related to each item. It recalculates everything transaction by transaction, as you said. This is the reason why you get the warning about it possibly running a long time. If you had a lot of items and a lot of (years of) transaction data, it would even crash in older 32 bit versions of B1.

Regards,

Johan

entry.title: 初めての Joule Skill 応用編：Automation で複数ユーザのバッジを一括リクエストしてみた
entry.content:
Joule Studio というサービスがリリースされてから約3ヶ月が経ちました。すでに SAP Tutorial にもいくつかコンテンツが公開されており、少しずつ盛り上がりを見せつつあります。一方で、「Joule Studio でどこまでできるのか？」という点は、まだ気になっている方も多いのではないでしょうか。

Tutorial の1つに 「Build Your First Joule Skill in Joule Studio」 というものがあります。以下のように、S/4 のモックからデータを参照する Action 、バッジを作成する Action を開発し、それらを利用した Joule Skill を開発する内容です。

In this tutorial, you will create an action project for accessing business partner information from an OData service representing an SAP system. You will also create an action project for creating a badge request via an OData service representing a third-party system.

 非常に勉強になる Tutorial なのですが、同僚から「例えば、複数のユーザを一気にバッジリクエストしたい場合はどうするの？」という質問をもらいました。確かに、このままの構成だと1ユーザずつ Joule にリクエストしないといけません。

それでは、複数ユーザ分をまとめてバッジリクエストできるようにしてみましょう。

ただし、ここで1つ問題があります。Joule Skill には、SBPA の Process でいうところの 「Go to Step」 や、Automation でいうところの 「forEach」 に相当するような、ループ制御の機能がありません。そのため、BusinessPartner の GET と Badge Create の POST を Joule Skill の中だけで繰り返し実行するのは難しい状況です。

そこで今回は、Automation を組み合わせる というアプローチを取ってみます。以下が完成形です。

　　

 

1. Joule Skill の仮組みを作成

Joule Skill からは Automation（および Process）を呼び出すことができます。今回は、Business Partner ID のリストを Automation に渡して処理させる構成にします。 ただし、Joule Skill 内における Automation への Input には Data Type の設定がなく、 String 型のみ です。

そのため、Joule 側では "AAAA, BBBB" のようにカンマ区切りの文字列として ID を入力してもらい、Automation 内で String から List of String に変換します。

  • Joule Skill の Input パラメータ名：BusinessPartnerList
  • Description：a list of BusinessPartner ID like "0001, 0002"

といった形で定義しておきます。

（元ネタの Tutorial では他にもいくつかパラメータを設定していますが、本記事では割愛します。）

 

2. Automation の作成

次に、Automation を作成します。一度 Joule Skill の開発画面から離れて、SAP Build Process Automation 側で Automation プロジェクトを作成します。

※ まだ Desktop Agent をセットアップしていない場合は、以下の URL を参考にセットアップしてください：
Install and Set Up Desktop Agent 3

最初に、Custom Script を使って String から List への変換を実装します。イメージは以下のような JavaScript 関数です。

function parseIds(rawIds) {
  if (typeof rawIds !== "string") {
    throw new Error("rawIds must be a string like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  const ids = rawIds
    .split(",")
    .map(s => s.trim())
    .filter(Boolean);

  if (ids.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("No valid IDs found. Expected something like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  return ids;
}

こうすることで、後続ステップで forEach を使って ID ごとの処理を実装できるようになります。

続いて、右上の Project Properties から Manage Dependencies → Add an Action Project Dependency を選択し、Tutorial で作成した Business Partner の GET と Badge Create の POST の Action Project を依存関係として追加します。

あとは、以下のようにフローを組みます。

  1. Input 文字列を String to List で List に変換
  2. forEach で ID を１件ずつ取り出す
  3. Get data from BP API の Action を呼び出す
  4. 結果を使って Create Badge の Action を呼び出す

最後に、Project Properties（右上の歯車マーク） → Attributes から、Agent セットアップ時に設定した Agent の属性を紐づけておきます。

準備ができたら、Release → Deploy を実行します。その後、Joule Skill から利用できるように、Lobby の該当バージョンで Publish to Library をクリックして公開します。

 

3. Automation の導入（Joule Skill 側）

再度 Joule Skill の画面に戻り、Run Automation を追加します。まずは、Browse All Automations から、先ほど作成した Automation を選択します。

Input パラメータ BusinessPartnerList を Automation の Input にマッピングします。

後続のステップに Send Message ノードを追加します。

これでフローが完成したら、Joule Skill 側でも Release → Deploy を実施します。

 

4. テスト

先ほども少し触れましたが、Automation には Agent が必要です（ここでいう Agent は、いわゆる AI エージェントではありません、念のため…）。

Joule Skill 内で Automation を実行する場合も、どの Agent を使うか を指定しておく必要があります。

Automation および Joule Skill をデプロイした環境に、Control Tower → Environments からアクセスします。その上で、Agent Management にて、対象の Agent を追加します。

ローカルの PC で動いている Desktop Agent の設定で、Agent Mode が Unattended になっていることを確認します。

一番右側のタブに「Joule」とあるので、作成した Joule Skill のバージョンを確認し、Launch ボタンから Joule にアクセスします。

実際にプロンプトを入力して試してみます。

それぞれの ID について Badge リクエストが登録されていることが確認できます。

やっていること自体は、Automation 側で forEach によるループを回しているだけなので、1件のリクエストにも複数件のリクエストにも対応できる構成になっています。

将来的にファイルアップロードが Joule Skill でサポートされれば、ファイルを元にさらに多くのリクエストを一括処理する、といったことも期待できそうです。

 

5. 最後に

いかがでしたでしょうか。既存の SAP Build Process Automation（SBPA）の知識をほとんどそのまま活かしながら、Joule Skill を拡張していくことができます。

一方で、

  • Go to Step のような柔軟なフロー制御が Joule Skill 側にないこと
  • Automation の Output を Joule Skill の変数に直接マッピングできないこと （Help には Output タブがあると記載されていますが、少なくとも私の環境ではまだ確認できていません）

など、現時点では少し物足りない部分があるのも事実です。 とはいえ、Joule Studio と SBPA を組み合わせることでできることは、今後さらに広がっていくはずです。これからのアップデートがとても楽しみです！

 

CoE Japan チームでは、Joule Studio だけでなく、様々な製品を対象に PoC やユースケース検証を実施しています。技術検証やアーキテクチャ検討、ベストプラクティスのご紹介などを通じて、お客様・パートナーの皆さまの SAP 活用を技術面からご支援しています。

Joule や SAP Build 周りで「こういうことはできる？」といったお悩みがあれば、ぜひ CoE Japan チームまでお気軽にご相談ください。

entry.title: Re: Connection error to CAP MCP servers in BAS with Cline
entry.content:
Hi @andreas_gall2,

you can use the SAP's MCP servers easily in any local IDE like VS Code with Cline. The configuration that you have used is also for such a local set up. SAP Build Code is not mandatory to use the MCP servers. We are working on an out-of-the-box integration of the SAP's MCP server in SAP Build Code, but that will take some more time.

If you really want to try it out in SAP Build Code, I added a new Cline configuration in exercise 0.3 in the Github repository https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2025-AD160/blob/main/exercises/ex0/README.md

The configuration in SAP Build Code is different, as your dev space is a virtual machine that runs in the cloud.

entry.title: Using an mqtt client with event mesh (python)
entry.content:
Hi,
I implemented a python script which connects to event mesh and subscribes to a queue.
The oauth token is retrieved successfully and the connection is established.
However every time the client tries to subscribe to a queue, the connection is closed.
This is also the case when the client tries sending a keepalive message.
This is my code:

import paho.mqtt.client as mqtt
import requests
import time

# ---------- Configuration ----------
BROKER_URL = "xxxx"      # Replace with your MQTT broker URL
BROKER_PORT = 443                     # Typically 8883 for TLS
TOPIC = "testOrgName/testEventMesh/1/test_queue"

# OAuth Configuration
OAUTH_TOKEN_URL = "xxx"  # OAuth token endpoint
CLIENT_ID = "xxx"
CLIENT_SECRET = "xxx"
SCOPE = "mqtt.subscribe"

# -----------------------------------

def get_oauth_token():
    """Fetch a new OAuth access token"""
    payload = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
    }
    response = requests.post(OAUTH_TOKEN_URL, auth=(CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET), params=payload)
    response.raise_for_status()
    token = response.json().get("access_token")
    return token

# MQTT Callbacks
def on_connect(client, userdata, flags, rc):
    if rc == 0:
        print("Connected successfully!")
        #client.subscribe(TOPIC)
        #client.publish(TOPIC, "Hello, MQTT!", qos=1)
        print(f"Subscribed to topic: {TOPIC}")
    else:
        print(f"Connection failed with code {rc}")

def on_message(client, userdata, msg):
    print(f"Received message: {msg.payload.decode()} on topic {msg.topic}")

def on_disconnect(client, userdata, rc):
    print(f"lost connection with reason {rc}")

def on_log(client, userdata, level, buf):
    print(f"{level}: {buf}")

def main():
    # Get OAuth token
    token = get_oauth_token()
    print("Obtained OAuth token")

    # Create MQTT client
    client = mqtt.Client(transport="websockets", client_id="xyz")

    # Assign callbacks
    client.on_connect = on_connect
    client.on_message = on_message
    client.on_disconnect = on_disconnect
    client.on_log = on_log

    # maybe not even necessary
    client.tls_set(ca_certs="./_.cf.eu10.hana.ondemand.com")
    client.ws_set_options(path="/protocols/mqtt311ws", headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"})

    # Connect to broker
    client.connect(BROKER_URL, BROKER_PORT)

    # Start network loop
    client.loop_start()

    try:
        while True:
            # Keep running or refresh token periodically if needed
            time.sleep(10)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("Disconnecting...")
        client.loop_stop()
        client.disconnect()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

 I have tried setting a different client id and I have verified that the topic coincides with the queue name and the queue naming rules in the service descriptor. I have also verified, that enough connections are open (there is no other connection). I also have verified, that the client is indeed connected to event mesh using the resource usage where it is, for some reason, marked as a producer.

My suspicion now is, that for some reason i have to enable the mqtt functionality or at least give some permissions for mqtt or something.

what would also be helpful would be something where i can see the logs of the mqtt broker in event mesh or at least any kind of logs.

entry.title: Disable Service and Asset Manager screen "Complete Operation"
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I have run into an issue while implementing SAP SAM (2405). It has to do with the SAP PM module and a role: Maintenance Technician (Professional).

The process of completing an operation goes like this:
1. Click "Add Confirmation" (this step doesn't matter, we just need to open the screen where Confirmations are created)
2. Confirmation Creation screen appears, called "Add Time Confirmation"
3. Let's say that this confirmation is final, so fill out our necessary data and set the indicator "Set as Final Confirmation" as active
4. Click "Save" in the top right corner of the screen to continue
5. If this confirmation is a final confirmation a new screen appears called "Complete Operation", which asks the user to add "Time" (if this was to be filled out, it would create another (unwanted) confirmation) and then asks for a text input via the "Notes" button – I can't figure out where this text is saved after saving it, but that is not that import anyways.

Now the main issue is, that by having this "Complete Operation" screen active, users are encouraged to create duplicate Final confirmations, which creates issues in the processing of Maintenance orders (and their operations) – SAP works with faulty data.

Up to this point, I believe that I have gone through the whole SSAM Help Portal to find an answer, yet there is nothing regarding a "Complete Operation" screen or how to disable it. With the screen active, the completion of operation process is unusable, as user would definitely use it incorrectly and fill out the unnecessary data, which would create a duplicate final confirmation. Is there anyone that has answers on how to disable the whole screen?

Note: I managed to disable the "Time" prompt by editing the SSAM Parameter PromptForTime = Y → N, yet that still leaves the screen and unnecessary processing time for the technicians on what to do with the screen – still not optimal (PromptForSignature set to N didn't remove the "Notes" prompt).

Thank you.

Kind regards,
Viktor

entry.title: Deploying SAP Cloud Connector 2.18 on AWS Free Tier Using CentOS Stream 9
entry.content:
Running SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) on AWS Free Tier sounds simple… until you realise that SCC’s default memory footprint overwhelms a 1-GB t2.micro instance. CentOS Stream 9 can run SCC 2.18 reliably with heap adjustments and automation.

Important:
SAP Cloud Connector 2.18 is not officially supported on CentOS Stream. This guide is strictly for training, sandboxing, and educational use.

Although this guide uses CentOS Stream 9 to remain within AWS Free Tier, the same Terraform and installation flow also works on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9, which is supported by SAP. If you intend to use SCC in a productive landscape, use RHEL.

1. Prerequisites

  • AWS account (EC2, VPC, S3 permissions)
  • Terraform installed locally
  • SSH client
  • A CentOS Stream 9 AMI (x86_64) for your region
  • An EC2 key pair
  • Basic understanding of shell scripting
  • An EC2 key pair (placeholder: <YOUR_KEY_PAIR>)
  • An S3 bucket containing the SCC ZIP file, for example:
<YOUR_S3_BUCKET>/sapcc-2.18.0-linux-x64.zip

Note: Direct downloads from tools.hana.ondemand.com return HTML instead of the ZIP file. Hosting the ZIP in S3 avoids this.

2. Project Directory

terraform_scc/
├── main.tf
├── install-scc.sh
├── <YOUR_KEY_PAIR.pem>
└── (optional) variables.tf / outputs.tf

3. Terraform Configuration (main.tf)

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = "us-east-2"
}

resource "aws_key_pair" "" {
  key_name   = "<YOUR_KEY_PAIR.pem>"
  public_key = file("${path.module}/")
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_scc_sg" {
  name        = "sap-scc-sg"
  description = "Allow SCC UI and SSH"
  vpc_id      = "<YOUR_VPC_ID>"

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  ingress {
    from_port   = 8443
    to_port     = 8443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  tags = {
    Name = "sap-scc-sg"
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_scc" {
  ami           = "<CENTOS_STREAM_9_AMI>"
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
  key_name      = aws_key_pair..key_name

  subnet_id                   = "<YOUR_SUBNET_ID>"
  associate_public_ip_address = true

  vpc_security_group_ids = [
    aws_security_group.sap_scc_sg.id
  ]

  user_data = file("${path.module}/install-scc.sh")

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-Cloud-Connector-CentOS"
  }
}

output "public_ip" {
  value = aws_instance.sap_scc.public_ip
}

4. Running Terraform

terraform init
terraform plan
terraform apply -auto-approve
terraform output -raw public_ip

To destroy:

terraform destroy -auto-approve

5. Installation Script (install-scc.sh)

#!/bin/bash
set -euxo pipefail

SCC_VERSION="2.18.0"
SCC_FILE="sapcc-${SCC_VERSION}-linux-x64.zip"

S3_BUCKET="<YOUR_S3_BUCKET>"
SCC_URL="https://${S3_BUCKET}.s3.amazonaws.com/${SCC_FILE}"

LOG_FILE="/var/log/scc-install.log"

exec > >(tee -a "${LOG_FILE}") 2>&1

echo "=== SAP Cloud Connector install on CentOS Stream 9 ==="
echo "Version: ${SCC_VERSION}"
echo "Source:  ${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Installing prerequisites ==="
dnf -y makecache
dnf -y install curl unzip java-11-openjdk-headless || dnf -y install java-17-openjdk-headless

cd /tmp

echo "=== Downloading SCC ==="
curl -L -o "${SCC_FILE}" "${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Verifying ZIP ==="
file "${SCC_FILE}" | grep -qi "Zip" || exit 1

echo "=== Extracting ==="
rm -rf /tmp/scc-installer
mkdir -p /tmp/scc-installer
unzip -o "${SCC_FILE}" -d /tmp/scc-installer
cd /tmp/scc-installer

RPM_FILE=$(ls com.sap.scc-ui-*.rpm | head -n 1)

echo "=== Installing SCC RPM ==="
dnf -y install --nogpgcheck "./${RPM_FILE}"

echo "=== Tuning JVM for t2.micro ==="
sed -i \
  -e 's/-Xms1024m/-Xms256m/' \
  -e 's/-Xmx1024m/-Xmx512m/' \
  -e 's/-XX:MaxNewSize=512m/-XX:MaxNewSize=256m/' \
  -e 's/-XX:NewSize=512m/-XX:NewSize=256m/' \
  /opt/sap/scc/props.ini || true

echo "=== Starting SCC ==="
systemctl enable scc_daemon.service || true
systemctl restart scc_daemon.service || true

echo "=== Waiting for port 8443 ==="
for i in {1..12}; do
  ss -tulpn | grep 8443 && break
  sleep 10
done

echo "=== SCC install complete ==="

6. SSH Access

ssh -i <YOUR_KEY_PAIR.pem> ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>

7. Accessing the SCC UI

https://<PUBLIC_IP>:8443

The default credentials are:

User: Administrator
Password: manage

After login, you will be prompted to set a new password.

8. Connecting SCC to SAP BTP

From BTP Cockpit collect:

  • Region code (example: us10)
  • Subaccount ID (GUID)
  • Subaccount user (your BTP e-mail)
  • Password (your IAS/BTP password)

In SCC navigate: Connector → Define Subaccount

9. Observations & Recommendations

  • SCC 2.18 is unsupported on CentOS; use RHEL in productive landscapes.
  • Heap tuning is mandatory on t2.micro.
  • Terraform ensures clean reproducibility.
  • Perfect for training, exams, PoCs.

10. Summary

You now have a free-tier compatible SCC 2.18 deployment running on CentOS Stream 9, launched automatically via Terraform, connected to BTP.

entry.title: Re: Field Control for Developer Extensibility Custom Fields
entry.content:
Hi @NaveenKoneru ,

as you are trying to add a standard field to the transactional behavior, I assume you are using a different field name in your extension e.g. TRATY => ZZTRATY. However, the standard business logic is not aware of this mapping unless there is some means to extend this in the application. This should be checked with the application development team for sales order.

However, one remark: adding standard fields to the transactional behavior can be problematic if the standard application adds this field in a later release as well...it is then enabled twice in the BO with different names -> RAP does not know which one to process. This will lead to a dump.

Regards,

Daniel

entry.title: Re: SAP ABAP object to get the classification tab details in MIGO before getting stored in DB
entry.content: To retrieve the classification tab values, the BAdI CACL_VALUE_CHANGE must be implemented. If these values are required in the implementation of the MIGO BAdI (for example, MB_DOCUMENT_BADI), ABAP Memory or SAP Memory can be used to transfer them from the buffer. However, in my case, neither ABAP Memory nor SAP Memory produced the desired results. Therefore, I opted for a custom table approach—first posting the data from the CACL_VALUE_CHANGE BAdI and subsequently retrieving it within the MIGO BAdI implementation.

entry.title: Re: Custom CDS view for 4JJ Scope item
entry.content:
Good day @gunadharshini 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Billing Document Item, Use SAP Build Process Automation

Yes, you are correct, that is the recommended approach for building the custom CDS view. Therefore, you can use the field from the I_BillingDocumentItem CDS view to replace RRBDynamicItem in your scenario.

My recommendation for you to achieve that would be to use the released I_BillingDocumentItem because it contains BillingDocumentItem, BillingDocument, WBS, Quantity, Posting Date, etc.

Depending on your requirement you may join with I_TimeSheetEntryDetail for your 4JJ time records, I_ConfirmationJournalEntryItem to post your costs and I_ServiceEntrySheetItem if SES is involved in your process.

That will result into your new custom CDS view providing billing status, time entry, billing document item reference which has replaced RRBDynamicItem and the necessary field required by BPA for you to create mass timesheet.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Standard cost estimate Value
entry.content:
Key areas to check

KP26 maintains the planned activity price (e.g., 28.54 per 60 minutes). Ensure the unit of measure (UoM) in KP26 matches the UoM used in the routing/recipe (minutes vs. hours).

In your routing, you’ve assigned 2800 minutes. If the system interprets this differently (e.g., converting minutes to hours), the calculation can change drastically.

The cost estimate calculates per costing lot size. If your costing lot size is not aligned with your manual calculation, the value shown (1.34 instead of 1331) could be scaled down.

entry.title: 📣 SAP Emarsys: Q4 2025 Product Release 📣
entry.content:
As marketers face mounting pressure to deliver deeply personalized, omnichannel experiences at scale, speed and efficiency have never been more essential. With our Q4 2025 Product Release, SAP Emarsys is helping marketers to meet these demands head-on - equipping them with smarter AI, stronger automation, and enhanced extensibility to drive measurable business outcomes across every channel. 

This quarter brings powerful innovations designed to connect deeper with customers, work more efficiently, and grow the business faster. 

Let’s dive in. 

Omnichannel Content That Converts 

To help you deliver consistent, high-performing experiences across all channels, we’ve expanded our prebuilt Omnichannel Content Blocks with new, flexible, reusable assets tailored specifically for Web Channel campaigns. These additions streamline content creation, reinforce brand consistency, and accelerate time-to-launch. 

We’ve also refreshed the Email Campaign List page with an improved Campaign Launch Monitoring tab and a redesigned Results summary page - accessible directly from the reporting icon.

Mobile Engagement with Wallet Passes & Event-Based Automation 

Mobile Wallet passes for event-based automations (formerly Interactions) are now generally available. Whether it’s a loyalty tier upgrade or a real-time purchase confirmation, marketers can trigger timely, behavior-based notifications that meet customers in the moment. 

Why it matters: Real-time personalization drives engagement and loyalty. 
See how CHRIST uses SAP Emarsys to transform every customer touchpoint into a meaningful interaction. 

Conversational Channels: More Control, More Insights 

We’ve expanded capabilities across WhatsApp and LINE with: 

  • Message deletion for removing outdated or underperforming messages to keep a tidy workspace 
  • Conversational Channel data views in Open Data for deeper campaign performance insights 
  • Session and Card messages with interactive buttons for surveys, guided journeys, and richer conversations  

The latest AI innovations 

The AI-assisted Report Builder is now generally available, making it easier than ever to generate custom reports, compare KPIs, and uncover customer and campaign insights instantly with natural language prompts. 

For product-rich campaigns, our AI-assisted Product Finder (Pilot) now supports API-loaded product data, enabling natural language queries with dynamic pricing and inventory relevance.  

Even better news - AI-assisted Product Finder is now free for all customers and will be accessible in customer accounts in the coming weeks! 

We've also enhanced Campaign Analytics with: 

  • A refreshed interface 
  • 13-month comparison windows 
  • Faster, simpler exports 

We’re expanding predictive segmentation (i.e. AI Segments) with a new Mobile Push engagement template, allowing you to target audiences most likely to engage via Push, besides Email or Web channels. 

Extensibility & Integration: More Data, More Possibilities 

The Standard Sales Data API is now generally available, enabling seamless onboarding of offline and online sales data for activation, segmentation, and reporting. With Sales Data Segmentation, you can incorporate purchase indicators such as refunds or local currency to refine audience targeting. 

This sales data can also power the AI-assisted Product Finder - for example, identifying the most-purchased product under €200 and inserting it directly into an email campaign. 

Engagement Events are now available to all customers with: 

  • Self-service setup 
  • API access 
  • Versioning logic for editing and testing events anytime 
  • Multi-event segmentation with AND/OR logic, frequency filters, and attribute controls 

Beyond simply triggering automation programs based on any type of event, customers can use the data from the event payload to further segment and personalize engagements throughout the journey. 

Additionally, SAP Commerce Cloud Integration ensures near-real-time transfer of engagement data, such as cart updates or purchases, to SAP Emarsys, supporting automation and transparency through the Integration Monitor. 

Connect and personalize: When sales, behavior, and engagement data come together, new levels of automation and personalization become possible.  

Platform Enhancements for Usability and Inclusion 

We’ve added Italian language support to the SAP Emarsys interface and introduced Asset Tagging in Segmentation (pilot), making it easier to organize, navigate, and collaborate across teams. 

 🎄

Holiday Readiness: Scale & Stability for Proven Success 

As the industry enters its busiest season, we’ve strengthened platform performance and reliability across key channels. Enhancements include: 

  • Improved email execution, deliverability, and monitoring 
  • Upgraded MTA infrastructure with better alerting 
  • Enhanced mobile deliverability 
  • Streamlined personalization, segmentation, and automation performance 

These upgrades empower brands to deliver high-volume, high-impact customer engagements with confidence throughout the holiday season. 

Your 2026 Marketing Momentum Begins Now 

The SAP Emarsys Q4 2025 product release marks another leap forward as marketers prepare for a pivotal holiday season and look ahead to 2026. Every enhancement is designed to help you do more with less, personalize at scale, drive customer loyalty and grow the business. 

Check out the Product Release Page here & don’t forget to register and invite your customers to the Product Release Webcast on November 25th. The session will be recorded and available on demand.

entry.title: Executing Dynamic SQL from a Parameterized View in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am working with SAP Datasphere and facing challenges executing dynamic SQL statements that are generated and stored in a parameterized view. I wanted to share my problem in detail and clarify the limitations I encountered, in case it helps others.

 

Scenario

I have a parameterized view DQ_RULE_GENERATED_VW that generates SQL statements dynamically based on some input parameters.

The view returns a column called GENERATED_SQL along with other metadata.

 

My goal is to execute these SQL statements dynamically within SAP Datasphere and capture the results in a table for downstream processing.

 

Challenges

1. Script Operators in Data Flows cannot execute arbitrary SQL:

    • Datasphere Python Script Operators only process DataFrames from upstream sources.
    • You cannot call a parameterized view directly or run SQL dynamically using sql.execute_query inside a Script Operator.

2. Parameterized views cannot be used as sources:

    • Script Operators and many Datasphere operators only accept materialized tables or non-parameterized views.

3. No direct write access to space-owned tables:

    • Even if I fetch results externally (e.g., with a Python script using a HANA connection), I cannot write the results back into Datasphere UI due to lack of privileges on space-owned tables.

    •  

    • I tried writing a stored procedure that executes the SQL statements dynamically, but it cannot write the results into the target table for the same reason. It seems DML operations can only be performed inside the Datasphere UI, not externally.

    •  

4. External execution works but is not automated:

  • I was able to fetch the GENERATED_SQL column using an external Python script, execute each statement dynamically, and get the results.
  • However, I cannot send the results back into Datasphere without write access.
  • Exporting results as CSV and manually uploading them is possible, but I would like a fully automated solution without manual steps.

 

Request for Community Input

I would like to know:

  1. Is there a fully supported way in Datasphere to execute SQL dynamically from a parameterized view?
  2. Are there recommended best practices for dynamically executing rules generated from parameterized views in Datasphere, especially when you don’t have write access to space-owned tables?

Any guidance or insights would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks,
Mayura

entry.title: Re: billFromParty and purchasingParty in Provider API for...
entry.content:
If the carrier cannot retrieve billFromParty and purchasingParty from the Freight Subcontracting Consumer API, they must still provide valid business partner IDs when calling the Provider API for Invoicing. In practice, this means the carrier needs to either

  • obtain these IDs from the freight order confirmation payload (where they are usually available if the ordering party has sent them), or
  • request the ordering party to supply the identifiers directly. Without these mandatory fields, the invoice cannot be processed in SAP Business Network for Logistics

entry.title: Kick-off SAP Community Belo Horizonte – Palestra com Breno Faria
entry.content:
Tema: BTP para você: simplificando o complexo com low-code, pro-code e automação
Data: 27/11 às 19h30

No nosso kick-off da SAP Community Belo Horizonte, teremos a honra de receber Breno Faria, Head of SAP BTP na Seidor Brasil, para uma palestra que promete destravar de vez o potencial da SAP BTP no dia a dia:
“BTP para você: simplificando o complexo com low-code, pro-code e automação.”

Em um cenário onde as empresas precisam inovar rápido, integrar sistemas legados e, ao mesmo tempo, manter governança e segurança, a SAP BTP se torna uma plataforma-chave. Breno vai mostrar, de forma prática e acessível, como combinar low-code, pro-code e automação para criar soluções modernas que realmente geram valor para o negócio – indo além do discurso e conectando tecnologia com resultado.

Sobre o palestrante

Breno Faria possui uma formação sólida e multidisciplinar em tecnologia e engenharia:

  • Pós-graduado em Sistemas Eletroeletrônicos e Automação Industrial pelo CEFET-MG
  • Graduado em Engenharia Mecânica pela Universidade de Itaúna (UIT)
  • Bacharel em Ciências da Computação pela Universidade de Itaúna (UIT)
  • Técnico em Eletrônica Aplicada pelo SENAI

Com atuação em análise, definição e desenvolvimento de sistemas desde 2002, Breno acumula ampla experiência especialmente no segmento industrial, com foco em soluções para engenharia de manufatura e múltiplos cenários de negócios.
Ao longo da carreira, tem se destacado como especialista em desenvolvimento de sistemas utilizando tecnologias de ponta, conectando chão de fábrica, aplicações corporativas e plataformas de inovação como a SAP BTP.

Hoje, como Head of SAP BTP na Seidor Brasil, Breno lidera iniciativas que envolvem:

  • Criação de soluções em BTP integrando diferentes sistemas SAP e não SAP
  • Uso de low-code e pro-code para acelerar a entrega de aplicações corporativas
  • Automação de processos para ganho de eficiência e redução de erros
  • Apoio a clientes em jornadas de inovação e transformação digital

Por que você não pode perder?

Se você trabalha com SAP, integração, desenvolvimento, automação ou está envolvido em iniciativas de inovação e transformação digital, essa palestra é para você.
Vamos discutir como tornar a BTP mais próxima da realidade do desenvolvedor e do negócio, mostrando caminhos para:

  • Começar com low-code, sem perder a flexibilidade do pro-code
  • Usar automação para simplificar fluxos complexos
  • Conectar a BTP de forma prática ao seu cenário atual

Reserve na agenda:
📅 27/11
🕤 19h30
📍Comunidade SAP Belo Horizonte (kick-off oficial)

Contamos com a sua presença para abrir esse novo ciclo da comunidade com muito conteúdo técnico, troca de experiências e networking!

entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I'm currently having doubts about the way to make the mapping of G/L Accounts with financial tags and income tax tags

1/ According to our system settings, costs or revenues assigned to a single G/L Account can come from both related or unrelated parties (whereas in a standard polish solution, tow different G/L accounts would exist, according to my customer). Therefore, it seems necessary to create tow different entries in the mapping table : "G/L Account + from related entity financial tag" and "G/L Account + from other entity financial tag".

My question is : when creating the report, how will the system differentiate the "from related entities / other entities"  journal entries since they use the same G/L Account. Will the system use the "trading partner"  information to decide which mapping should be applied ? Are there other sscui settings to use for that purpose ?

2/ In the same idea, different tax codes can be assigned to transactions posted on the same G/L Account. So we have to make as many entries in the mapping table as as there are different combinations of G/L account, financial tag, and income tax tag. Is it necessary to make an additional mapping between tax codes that exist in the system and the "official" income tax tags, so that the system correctly assign the mapping to a specific journal entry ?

=> for both questions could it be usefull/necessary to create a Badi to implement dynamic determination of the tags ?

Thank you for your help,

Erwan

entry.title: Consuming DPI Service using Client Certificate Authentication
entry.content:
This blog provides a clear, step-by-step walkthrough of implementing client certificate authentication in an SAP BTP landscape.  It outlines how to configure the required artifacts, and demonstrates how to integrate them into your application. You’ll also find practical guidance for testing your setup ensuring secure communication between services using mutual TLS. Whether you're new to certificate authentication or looking for a quick reference, this guide offers a concise and hands-on approach to getting it right.

  • Introduction:
  • Overview:
  • Steps:
  • Pre-Requisite :
  • Testing with direct call to DRM Endpoint
  • Testing withcustom API endpoint implemented in the backend service

Introduction:

Client Certificate Authentication is a secure method used in SAP BTP to verify the identity of an application making a request to a service. Instead of relying on passwords or OAuth tokens, the calling client presents an X.509 certificate during the TLS handshake. The service then validates this certificate against trusted authorities before allowing access.

In the SAP BTP landscape, this mechanism is commonly used when applications communicate with platform services—such as Destination Service, or custom apps deployed on Cloud Foundry. By configuring a certificate as a service key, destination, or trust configuration, SAP BTP ensures that only verified clients can call protected endpoints.

This method offers stronger security for machine-to-machine communication because certificates are harder to compromise, can be automatically rotated, and can be scoped strictly to the required service.

Overview:

We are using destination certificate to consume the services provided by the Data Privacy Integration (DPI) service. This certificate is used to authenticate the endpoints that we have implemented. Since we are operating in asynchronous mode, we must also send a status update to the callback endpoint after the archiving process is completed. Accordingly, the destination certificate is also used to authenticate requests to the callback endpoint.

We created a service instance of the data-privacy-integration-service using the data-privacy-internal plan. The Data Privacy Integration (DPI) service validates the certIssuer and certSubject either through the service key or through service bindings. As per the required procedure, we generated the service key accordingly. The remaining steps are outlined in the following section.

Steps:

Pre-Requisite :

  1. Create a destination certificate. Make sure to use the P12 extension while creating the certificate and choose the validity based on your requirement. Password is given to decode the certificate later. You can choose it to be empty.
    Certificate Creation on BTP
  2. The certificate will be generated with a public X.509 certificate and a private key.

    Destination Certificate on BTP
  3. Create a destination. Provide the target URL that you want to connect to. Choose ClientCertificateAuthentication from the drop down. In the Key Store Location select the certificate that you created in the previous step.

    New Destination from Scratch
  4. Destination is created with the following details.

    Destination Details
  5. To create a service key, we need to specify the parameters. The values must be obtained from the X.509 certificate created earlier.

Service Key


We tested it both via REST API Client and through a custom API implementation in one of our backend services.

Testing with direct call to DRM Endpoint

To test via REST API client, we need to get access to the certificate and key. With the export button on UI, you can excess only the public certificate. Hence, we need to use the APIs provided by cloud-sdk to access the destination certificate.

Send a GET request to https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates

Choose OAuth and Client Credentials in Auth section
Obtain the credentials from the service key of destination-service service instance.
Accessing Destination Certificates created in BTP SubaccountThe response body will have the following format.

{
 {
    “Name”: “trial.p12”,
    “Type”: “CERTIfICATE”,
    “Content”: “<encoded-content>”
 }
}​

Copy the content and save it in a Trial.txt file. Use the following command to decode it and save it in a cert file.

cat Trial.txt | base64 -d > Trial.p12​

Use the command to check how the decoded file looks like. You can press enter for “Enter Import Password:”, since we did not provide any password while creating the certificate. This should show the certificate on screen.

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes​

We need to save certificate and key into two separate files.
To save the certificate: 

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes -out TrialCert.crt -nokeys ​

To save the key: 

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes -out TrialKey.key -nocerts

There may be some sections with “Bag Attributes”. We can manually correct both the certificate and key files by removing these sections.

Go to your REST API Client. We are using Bruno. Add the cert and key that was created in the previous steps, along with the domain of the url you want to send request to.

Adding the Certificate in Client Certificate Section
Sending Request from Bruno


Testing with custom API endpoint implemented in the backend service

To test via custom API endpoint implemented in the backend service, we need to integrate BTP Destination Service.

Bind Connectivity and Destination Services
To enable destination-based outbound communication, ensure that both the Connectivity Service and Destination Service are bound to the required subaccount. This setup is mandatory for the application to resolve destinations at runtime.

Add the Destination Service Dependency
Include the Cloud SDK destination service artifact in the project’s pom.xml. This dependency provides the APIs required to fetch destinations and manage authentication.

<dependency>
     <groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk.cloudplatform</groupId>
     <artifactId>connectivity-destination-service</artifactId>
 </dependency>​

Fetching the Destination (Subscriber vs. Provider Context)
If the destination is maintained in the subscriber subaccount, fetching it is straightforward because the application already runs in the subscriber’s tenant context:

var service = new DestinationService();
DestinationOptions options;
Try<Destination> destination = service.tryGetDestination("destination-name", options);

In our case, the destination “TRIAL_AUTH” is maintained in the provider subaccount.
Therefore, we must explicitly specify the retrieval strategy ALWAYS_PROVIDER so that the destination is fetched from the provider tenant:

DestinationService service = new DestinationService();

DestinationOptions options = DestinationOptions.builder()
      .augmentBuilder(DestinationServiceOptionsAugmenter
      .augmenter()     
      .retrievalStrategy(DestinationServiceRetrievalStrategy.ALWAYS_PROVIDER))
      .build();

Try<Destination> destinationTry = service.tryGetDestination(“TRIAL_AUTH”, options);
Destination destination = destinationTry.get();

Create and Execute the HTTP Request Using the Resolved Destination
Once the destination has been resolved, retrieve the HTTP client from it.
The Cloud SDK automatically applies the authentication and configuration defined in the destination.

// Convert the destination to an HTTP destination
 HttpDestination httpDestination = destination.asHttp();
 
 // Obtain an HTTP client instance
 HttpClient client = HttpClientAccessor.getHttpClient(destination);
 
 // Create a generic HTTP request (e.g., HttpPut / HttpPost / HttpGet / tec)
 HttpRequestBase request = new HttpPut(httpDestination.getUri().toString());
 // Example: Replace with new HttpPost(...) or new HttpGet(...)or others as needed
 
 // --- Set headers (example) ---
 request.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");
 request.setHeader("Accept", "application/json");
 // Add any additional headers here...
 
 // --- Set payload (only applies to entity-enclosing requests like PUT/POST/others) ---
 StringEntity requestBody = new StringEntity(payload, "UTF-8");
 if (request instanceof HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase) {
     ((HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase) request).setEntity(requestBody);
 }
 
 // Execute the HTTP request
 HttpResponse response = client.execute(request);

To verify the custom API endpoint through a REST client, we used Bruno to trigger the backend service and validate the destination-based connectivity.  Add the cert and key (if cert-based authentication is enabled in your backend service)

Adding certificate

Sending Request from Bruno

entry.title: Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection
entry.content:
Create a Formation to Integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

Prerequisites

  • You are an SAP global account administrator, or you are a system landscape administrator.

  • SAP Analytics Cloud can run on Hana 2.0 or HANA Cloud.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must be located in the same data center and deployed in the same landscape. SAP data centers are not in the scope.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must use the same identity provider (IdP) and the same subject name identifier.

  • Ensure the relevant SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants or systems in your landscape are available to be integrated in a formation.

  • Context

    A formation is created in SAP BTP cockpit in the System Landscape section of your global account. The formation identifies the systems that can connect with your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

    Formations enable the automated integration between a set of your provisioned SAP systems.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape  Systems page, browse the systems in your customer system landscape.
      Every SAP Analytics Cloud system and SAP Datasphere system you are going to include in this formation must not be apart of another formation. The system landscape features auto-discovered systems in the list.
      • Note

        if a given system is missing on the Systems page, it may be associated with a different customer ID on the SAP BTP global account you're working in. In this case you need to add the system manually, and then register it. For more information, see Adding, Registering, and Deregistering Systems.

    2. Go to System Landscape   Formations. Select Create Formation.
      1. In the General Information step, enter a descriptive formation name.
      2. In the Formation Type drop-down menu, select Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.
    3. Select Next Step.
    4. In the Include Systems step, select the SAP Datasphere tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud tenant you want to link with.
    5. Select Next Step.
    6. Review your selections and create the formation.

    Results

    The formation appears under your list of formations and a Ready success message is shown.

    Delete a Formation in SAP BTP Cockpit

    Context

    When you delete a formation, the following happens. Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants will be excluded from the formation. Then, the subaccount is unassigned. Finally, the SAP Analytics Cloud formation is removed from the Formations page completely.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit go to System Landscape  Formations.
    2. Select the formation of SAP Analytics Cloud that you want to remove.
    3. Select Delete at the top-right of the formation.

    Recreation of Formation

    When formation is recreated the scheduling feature will be enabled again. The functionalities will continue to work as they were before the deletion. For scheduling, UCL formation will only provide enablement of tunneled connections.

    As a next step to create Tunnel connection and perform scheduling of SAC story based on DSP live connectivity please follow the help document. 

    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/18850a0e13944f53aa8a8b7c094ea29e/1c4c615f5d7f4b78a5ae681759a55650.html?version=2025.23

entry.title: [SAC] Minor inconvenience on responsive functionnality since the update. Bug or intended ?
entry.content:
Hello everyone, 

I have been working on making my reports responsive recently, and since the last update, I encounter a little issue, which I wanted to share with you, in order to have more information about it, or if it is not intended, simply report that this exists.

When you are in the builder panel of your section, working to adapt the size of your widget, you have the possibility to switch from 'Free' to 'Auto-Flow'. 

My issue comes up when you want to add a widget in the 'Widget Width' or 'Height' section. In free mode, you can 'Add widget', and then you have a Drop-down panel to choose the widget you wish to adapt.  And as long as I remember, it always worked like this. 

 

 

But now, when I switch to Auto-flow, the drop-down still exists, but does not allow me to select other widgets, so I have to add all my widgets first, and then adapt the sizes.

 

 

I don't know if this was intended, but I find it a bit annoying since the report updates only when all fields are filled in.

Let me know if you face the same problem, and if anyone has information about it, I would be really interested !

entry.title: Scheduling SAP Analytics Cloud Stories Based on SAP Datasphere Live Connections
entry.content:
Overview

(Available Starting QRC4 2025)

Scheduled publications are an important feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), enabling organizations to distribute stories at regular intervals for offline access over email email delivery.

As SAP Datasphere continues to be the strategic data foundation for SAP customers, many organizations rely extensively on live connections between SAC and Datasphere. Starting with SAP Analytics Cloud QRC4 2025, customers can now schedule publications for stories built on SAP Datasphere live connections.

This capability is supported for:

  • SAP Analytics cloud and SAP Datasphere on BDC Tenant
  • Standalone (non-BDC) SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant

Prerequisites

To schedule a story based on a Datasphere live connection, the story must use an SAP Datasphere Tunnel Connection.

Creating a Datasphere Tunnel Connection

A Tunnel Connection can be created only when SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are “deep linked.” Deep linking ensures seamless authentication, metadata access, and cross-system operations.

Deep linking configurations:

  • Option 1 — In BDC tenant where SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are linked via BDC formation (Recommended)
  • Option 2 — In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant and SAP Datasphere tenant (Non BDC) are linked via UCL formation.  (Recommended) - Refer to blog Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection 
  • Option 3 — SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant are linked for seamless planning as below 

     

Once any one of the above configurations is done, In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can create a SAP Datasphere Tunnel connection using below step

  • From the side navigation, choose Connections  
  • Click Add + Connection
  • Expand Connect to Live Data and select SAP Datasphere.
  • In the dialog, enter a name and description for your connection.
  • From the Connection Type drop-down list, select Tunnel
    • Tunnel connection type is mandatory if you plan to use this Scheduled Publications using the Datasphere Live connection.
    • For tunnel connections, ensure both SAC and Datasphere users use the same Identity Provider (IdP)

Note: In QRC4.2025, you have an option to create new Tunnel connection, however, you will not be able to convert existing SAP Datasphere Direct connection to Tunnel connection. However, if you are on Fast track tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud version 2025.23 or beyond then you can edit Direct connection to Tunnel Connection. If you are on QRC tenant, then this will be available in QRC1.2026

 

Scheduling a Story Based on a Datasphere Live Connection

Once the Tunnel Connection is created and used in the story, it can be scheduled like any other SAC story, with support for email distribution, CSV/Excel/PDF/PowerPoint output, recurrence, dynamic time filters, and personalization.

Conclusion

Starting QRC4 2025, this enhancement supports Scheduling Publication of SAP Analytics Cloud story capabilities for customers using SAP Datasphere with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Field Control for Developer Extensibility Custom Fields
entry.content:
Hi @NaveenKoneru,

as mentioned in my earlier reply, I assume the field mapping is not done. When you read an entity with EML, the implementation of the read must consider this field. For end2end extension fields this is done automatically (field names in CDS and db table must be identical). As you are now using a standard field, this is simply not read by the application implementation.

Note: thats just my assumption, as I am not an expert of the sales order app. So you might need to get in contact with SAPs SD dev team.
